html:
Synopsis

"The valuation of India has become very significant, and investors are taking their profit," said Baudson in an interview during her recent visit to India. Amundi is a stakeholder in SBI Mutual Fund, owning 37% of the country's largest asset manager. SBI owns 63%.

Mumbai: Valerie Baudson is not worried at all about the recent sell-off in Indian equities. On the contrary, the chief executive officer of France's Amundi, Europe's largest asset manager handling ₹2.2 trillion of investor money globally, is convinced that India remains a bright spot despite the recent growth concerns as she is 'incredibly' confident about the prospects of the country and its equities in the long run.

"The valuation of India has become very significant, and investors are taking their profit," said Baudson in an interview during her recent visit to India. Amundi is a stakeholder in SBI Mutual Fund, owning 37% of the country's largest asset manager. SBI owns 63%.

"I think what is happening is not at all worrying in the long run and I'm absolutely convinced that international investors will invest more and more in the long-run in India, both in equities and in bonds, because at the end of the day, the fundamentals are here."

Since October 1, foreign portfolio investors have pulled ₹2.5 lakh crore (or $29 billion) out of Indian equities - their highest selling ever.

Baudson is bullish on India because of growth, internal demand, technological strength, financial stability and the country's growing role in the global value chain.

India vs China
She sees the pace of India's economic growth outdoing China's over the next few years.

"In China, we know that the economic growth will decrease, because of the debt levels of economic players, real estate and the need for more internal growth than external growth in the current environment," said Baudson. "All this is structural, and last but not least, the demographic trend is certainly not the same as India's."

Trade Tariffs
She is not too worried about the escalating trade tariff tensions emanating from the US for the past few weeks, though in the short term, the focus will be on that.

"What I believe is that the current American administration is quite pragmatic at the end of the day, and very business-oriented," said Baudson. "Though it is obviously working in the interest of the US, in the long run, the tariff war is not good for anybody. It's quite bad for everybody."

India will not be as impacted by the trade tariff compared to some other regions like China or Mexico, she said.

US economy
Amundi expects growth in the US to soften in 2025, while Europe will pick up.

"It will of course depend on the decisions made politically, which are not all known, but we know already that the American GDP growth will decrease a little bit," said Baudson. "On the other side, Europe will grow, especially because inflation has been completely mastered. The ECB has done a very good job, and we see some additional decrease in rates in 2025."
